{{ _('Welcome') }}

{%trans%} PyCox is a python package which implements algorithms to carry out symbolic computations with Coxeter groups and related mathematical structures. It may be considered as a Python version of the original CHEVIE package which was written in GAP3 and MAPLE. However, it also contains functionality which is not present in the original CHEVIE package. People familiar with CHEVIE will be quite at home using PyCox but a knowledge of CHEVIE is not necessary to use the software. {%endtrans%}

{%trans%}Citing PyCox{%endtrans%}

{%trans%} If you use PyCox as part of a research project then you can reference the following article written by Geck. {%endtrans%}

{%trans%} M. Geck, PyCox: computing with (finite) Coxeter groups and Iwahori-Hecke algebras, LMS J. Comput. Math. 15 (2012), 231-256. {%endtrans%}

{%trans%} You can of course also cite this documentation as a reference point for PyCox. If you have used PyCox for some research then please tell us about it by contacting one of the contributors! {%endtrans%}

{%trans%}Why Python?{%endtrans%}

{%trans%} One of the original reasons for choosing Python as the language for PyCox is the success of the Sage project. In particular, PyCox may be used in Sage by simply importing PyCox in an interactive session. Here are some additional reasons: {%endtrans%}

  • {%trans%} Python is very popular with the wider scientific community (see for instance the SciPy project). {%endtrans%}
  • {%trans%} It is easy to encorporate C extensions into Python, thus allowing one to obtain speed advantages when needed. {%endtrans%}
  • {%trans%} As Python is a widely used modern programming language, anyone learning to use PyCox for research will simultaneously gain a useful transferable skill. {%endtrans%}
  • {%trans%} The Python language is syntactically similar to the GAP3 language, on which the original CHEVIE package was based. Thus it should not be difficult for people to switch between the two languages. {%endtrans%}
